Abstract: The study of extracellular electron transfer (EET) mechanisms in bacteria such as Shewanella and Geobacter has unveiled significant insights into microbial energy conversion processes. These bacteria utilize specialized proteins, including cytochromes, to facilitate electron transfer beyond their outer membranes, enabling interactions with external electron acceptors. This research explores the intricate pathways and molecular components involved in EET, emphasizing the role of cytochromes and electron shuttles in mediating these processes. By examining the structural and functional dynamics of these proteins, the study aims to elucidate the mechanisms by which electrons are effectively 'put to rest' in external acceptors. Understanding these processes not only advances our knowledge of microbial metabolism but also holds potential for biotechnological applications, such as bioenergy production and bioremediation. This research contributes to the broader understanding of microbial electron transfer and its implications for environmental and industrial processes.
